senses.de: Precise and accurate, leaving no room for uncertainty
senses.ex: The exact cost of the project is not yet known.

Tips.title: Precision Needed
Tips.description: Use 'exact' when details are crucial and one needs to avoid misunderstandings.
Tips.example: Please provide the exact measurements of the shelf.

Tips.title: Uncertainty Indicator
Tips.description: 'Exact' signals that you are looking for or giving specific information.
Tips.example: He couldn't remember the exact words she used.

Tips.title: Lacks Flexibility
Tips.description: Conveys a sense that there is no flexibility or estimate; only the precise fact is acceptable.
Tips.example: They agreed to meet at the exact time of 3 p.m.

senses.de: To demand and get something, especially by using your authority
senses.ex: The court ordered that the defendant must exact damages from the plaintiff.

Tips.title: Authority or Power
Tips.description: Highlights the use of power or authority when getting what is demanded.
Tips.example: The government will exact taxes from all working citizens.

Tips.title: Not Always Money
Tips.description: Remember, what's exacted can be an action, not just a fee or payment.
Tips.example: The queen exacted a promise of loyalty from her knights.

senses.de: Being the same in all ways
senses.ex: This is the exact same shirt I lost last month.

Tips.title: Perfect Match
Tips.description: Suggests that two things are not just similar, but identical in every way.
Tips.example: I found the exact same dress in another store.

senses.de: To force someone to experience a difficult or unpleasant situation
senses.ex: The king exacted tribute from his subjects.

Tips.title: Imposition of Hardship
Tips.description: Conveys causing someone to bear something difficult or harsh.
Tips.example: The conqueror exacted heavy tributes from the population.

Tips.title: Historical Connotation
Tips.description: It often refers to historical or antiquated practices of authority and submission.
Tips.example: In medieval times, lords exacted obedience from their vassals.

senses.de: Having or showing very strict moral behaviour
senses.ex: He lived his life according to his own exact moral code.

Tips.title: High Standards
Tips.description: Emphasizes someone’s uncompromising adherence to very specific rules or ethics.
Tips.example: His exacting standards for the project left no room for errors.

Tips.title: Not Flexible
Tips.description: Often paired with routines or methods that admit no deviation or flexibility.
Tips.example: He follows an exact regimen for his morning routine.

Accurate.wordDefinition:
The words accurate and exact are sometimes used interchangeably, but they actually have slightly different meanings. Accurate means close to the correct or expected result, but not necessarily identical.

For example, if you measure a table and get a result of 3 feet and 3 inches, an accurate measurement might be within a quarter of an inch of that, while an exact measurement would be exactly 3 feet and 3 inches, without any rounding or approximation.

Accurate is used when a result is close to the expected answer, but not necessarily identical, while exact is used when the result is completely correct and precise, without any deviation.

Correct.wordDefinition:
Correct means that something is right or accurate. For example, if your answer to a math problem is correct, it means you got it right.

Correct is used more often in everyday situations when something is simply right or accurate. Exact is used when something needs to be completely precise, like in scientific or mathematical contexts.

Definite.wordDefinition:
Definite suggests that something is certain or clear, while exact refers to something that is precise or accurate.

For example, if you say "I am definitely going to the party," it means that you have made up your mind and there is no doubt.

Definite is often used to describe things that are certain or distinct, while exact describes things that are accurate or precise.

Meticulous.wordDefinition:
Meticulous means something that is done with great attention to detail. It means that something is done very carefully and precisely, with the intention of getting everything right.

You might use the word meticulous when you want to describe someone's attention to detail or their carefulness, like when you say that your friend is meticulous about keeping their room clean.

Precise.wordDefinition:
Exact means completely accurate without any mistakes or errors, while the word precise means accurate to a very detailed level.

If you were building a model airplane, you would need to be precise in your measurements because even a slight difference in measurement can affect the final product.

Exact refers to accuracy without errors, while precise refers to accuracy at a very detailed level. Both words are applicable in different contexts, depending on the level of accuracy needed.

Rigorous.wordDefinition:
Rigorous refers to something that is thorough, careful, and strict.

For example: "The scientist's rigorous testing process ensured that the results were accurate and reliable."

So, while exact refers to precision and correctness, rigorous refers to the amount of effort and strictness involved in achieving that precision and correctness.

Specific.wordDefinition:
Both words refer to being clear and precise, but exact implies being completely accurate or correct in all details, whereas specific implies being clearly defined or identified in a particular way.

For example, if someone asks for the exact time, they want an answer that is completely accurate down to the second. If someone asks for a specific time, they may be referring to a particular hour or minute, but not necessarily down to the second.

Specific is applicable when something needs to be clearly defined or identified in a particular way, such as in instructions or descriptions.

Strict.wordDefinition:
Strict means following rules or guidelines very closely, with no exceptions. It is applicable when someone wants a discipline to be rigorously followed or when someone is following a set of rules or regulations.

If a teacher asks a student to follow strict rules regarding classroom behavior, the student should never violate those rules under any circumstances.

quotes.Text: I've been on tour since I was 16, and I always do meet-and-greets before and after shows, so you kind of build these friendships with people. I have girls come up to me and tell me exactly what's going on in their love lives.
quotes.Title: American Singer
quotes.Name: Taylor Swift

quotes.Text: I feel like I write so that people can think of it as theirs. If my song is exactly about your life right now, then it is - I don't even want to say that it's mine, because it's yours.
quotes.Title: American Singer
quotes.Name: Billie Eilish

quotes.Text: I think it makes sense to believe in God, but exactly what decision in your life you make differently because of it, I don't know.
quotes.Title: American Businessman
quotes.Name: Bill Gates

quotes.Text: Success is like reaching an important birthday and finding you're exactly the same.
quotes.Title: British Actress
quotes.Name: Audrey Hepburn

quotes.Text: Looking at yourself in a mirror isn't exactly a study of life.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Lauren Bacall

quotes.Text: If you know exactly what your character knows, it's a drama.
quotes.Title: Director
quotes.Name: Timur Bekmambetov

quotes.Text: Everyone thinks I am exactly like the characters I play.
quotes.Title: Indian Actor
quotes.Name: Jitendra Kumar

quotes.Text: Missing your lunch is not exactly the end of the world.
quotes.Title: British Soldier
quotes.Name: Mike Jackson

quotes.Text: Life is not an exact science, it is an art.
quotes.Title: British Poet
quotes.Name: Samuel Butler

quotes.Text: My life is exactly the way it needs to be.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Octavia Spencer
